questions.text: A 60-year-old diabetic male presents with a history of decreased vision. Fluorescein angiography showed the following image. What is the most likely diagnosis? ( AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Proliferative diabetic retinopathy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Proliferative diabetic retinopathy is the advanced stage of diabetic eye disease, marked by neovascularization, which requires aggressive treatment like laser photocoagulation to prevent severe visual loss. It is crucial for diabetics, particularly those with a long history or poorly controlled diabetes, to undergo regular eye examinations for early detection and management of diabetic retinopathy.

questions.text: What is the dye and filter used as seen in the image? (NEET PG 2018)

options.label: A
options.text: Fluorescein dye - visualised under cobalt blue filter

options.label: D
options.text: Fluorescein dye - visualised under green filter

questions.correct_answer: A. Fluorescein dye - visualised under cobalt blue filter
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Fluorescein dye - visualised under cobalt blue filter

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ In ophthalmology, different dyes and filters are used to aid in the diagnosis of various conditions. Fluorescein dye is visualized using a cobalt blue filter, which causes it to fluoresce and highlights areas of corneal compromise. It is crucial to use the appropriate filter for each dye to accurately diagnose and assess ocular surface disorders.

questions.text: Mother had painful vesicular lesions over genitalia one year back. Baby is born with features of meningitis and fever and rashes in abdomen and forearm and died within a week. Scrapings from lesions showed multinucleate giant cells. What is the most likely organism? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.correct_answer: A. Herpes Simplex Virus type 2 ( HSV2)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Herpes Simplex Virus type 2 (HSV2)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The correct answer is HSV2 (Herpes Simplex Virus Type 2). The clinical history provided in the question strongly suggests neonatal herpes infection. The mother had a history of painful vesicular lesions over the genitalia, which is characteristic of genital herpes caused by HSV2. Neonatal herpes can be transmitted from the mother to the baby during childbirth if the mother has an active HSV infection. The baby presented with symptoms of meningitis, fever, and rash, which are typical manifestations of neonatal herpes. The presence of multinucleated giant cells on scrapings from lesions further supports the diagnosis, as these are characteristic findings in herpes infections.
  • • The correct answer is HSV2 (Herpes Simplex Virus Type 2). The clinical history provided in the question strongly suggests neonatal herpes infection.
  • • The mother had a history of painful vesicular lesions over the genitalia, which is characteristic of genital herpes caused by HSV2.
  • • Neonatal herpes can be transmitted from the mother to the baby during childbirth if the mother has an active HSV infection.
  • • The baby presented with symptoms of meningitis, fever, and rash, which are typical manifestations of neonatal herpes.
  • • The presence of multinucleated giant cells on scrapings from lesions further supports the diagnosis, as these are characteristic findings in herpes infections.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Enterovirus 70:
  • • Option B. Enterovirus 70:
  • • Enterovirus 70 is associated with acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis, not with vesicular lesions or the neonatal symptoms described in the question. It does not typically cause multinucleated giant cells in lesions.
  • • Enterovirus 70 is associated with acute hemorrhagic conjunctivitis, not with vesicular lesions or the neonatal symptoms described in the question.
  • • It does not typically cause multinucleated giant cells in lesions.
  • • Option C. Human Papillomavirus (HPV) :
  • • Option C. Human Papillomavirus (HPV)
  • • HPV causes warts and is associated with genital warts, but it does not cause painful vesicular lesions or neonatal meningitis. HPV also does not produce multinucleated giant cells on lesion scrapings.
  • • HPV causes warts and is associated with genital warts, but it does not cause painful vesicular lesions or neonatal meningitis.
  • • HPV also does not produce multinucleated giant cells on lesion scrapings.
  • • Option D. VZV:
  • • Option D. VZV:
  • • Varicella-Zoster Virus (VZV) can cause vesicular lesions, but the clinical scenario described (painful genital lesions in the mother) and the findings in the neonate (multinucleated giant cells and severe systemic symptoms) are more consistent with HSV2 rather than VZV.
  • • Varicella-Zoster Virus (VZV) can cause vesicular lesions, but the clinical scenario described (painful genital lesions in the mother) and the findings in the neonate (multinucleated giant cells and severe systemic symptoms) are more consistent with HSV2 rather than VZV.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Herpes Simplex Virus Type 2 (HSV2) is the most likely organism causing neonatal herpes, characterized by the presence of painful vesicular lesions in the mother and severe systemic symptoms including meningitis, fever, and rash in the newborn, along with multinucleated giant cells found in lesion scrapings.
  • ➤ Herpes Simplex Virus Type 2 (HSV2) is the most likely organism causing neonatal herpes, characterized by the presence of painful vesicular lesions in the mother and severe systemic symptoms including meningitis, fever, and rash in the newborn, along with multinucleated giant cells found in lesion scrapings.

questions.text: Which is the most common lacrimal gland tumor? ( AIIMS May 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Pleomorphic adenoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common lacrimal gland tumor. It is usually benign and arises from the glandular tissue. It can sometimes have a mixture of cell types, hence the name "pleomorphic."

questions.text: A diabetic patient presented to you with visual acuity of 6/9 in one eye. Further investigations revealed pre-retinal hemorrhages with neovascularization at the optic disc. What is the next step in management? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Pan-retinal photocoagulation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pan-retinal photocoagulation (PRP) is the recommended management for proliferative diabetic retinopathy with high-risk characteristics such as neovascularization at the optic disc and pre-retinal hemorrhages.

questions.text: Which of these options are considered direct gonioscopes?( INICET May 2023) Goldmann Richardson Zeis Koeppe
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 2, 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Direct gonioscopes like Richardson and Koeppe provide a detailed and direct view of the anterior chamber angle, which is valuable in diagnostic and certain therapeutic procedures.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presents to his primary care physician with complaints of double vision, drooping of his right eyelid, and difficulty swallowing, especially in the evening hours. He mentions that his symptoms are mild in the morning but worsen throughout the day, making it hard for him to keep his eyes open and causing slurred speech by late afternoon. He denies any history of trauma, recent infections, or significant changes in his medications. His medical history includes hypertension, managed with lifestyle modifications. During the examination, the physician notices right-sided ptosis and weakness in the extraocular muscles without any sensory loss or abnormal pupillary reflexes. The physician decides to administer a short-acting medication intravenously to assess the response, and within minutes, the patient’s symptoms improve significantly, with resolution of ptosis and improved speech clarity. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Myasthenia Gravis (MG) is an autoimmune disorder characterized by fluctuating muscle weakness due to the destruction of acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction by autoantibodies. Patients typically present with symptoms that worsen with activity and improve with rest, such as ptosis, diplopia, and bulbar symptoms including dysphagia and slurred speech. In this patient’s case, the classic pattern of worsening symptoms throughout the day and improvement after rest is highly suggestive of MG. The dramatic response to anticholinesterase medications, like edrophonium, confirms the diagnosis by temporarily increasing acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction, which improves muscle strength. Additional tests, including the ice pack test and acetylcholine receptor antibody testing, can further support the diagnosis.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Lambert-Eaton Myasthenic Syndrome: This condition is associated with antibodies against presynaptic calcium channels, leading to impaired acetylcholine release. Symptoms often include proximal muscle weakness that improves with activity, unlike MG, and it does not show significant improvement with anticholinesterase medications.
  • • Option
  • • A. Lambert-Eaton Myasthenic Syndrome:
  • • Option B. Botulism: Botulism results from a neurotoxin that inhibits acetylcholine release at the neuromuscular junction, causing descending paralysis, ptosis, and dysphagia. However, it typically progresses more rapidly and does not respond to anticholinesterase medications. Autonomic features such as fixed, dilated pupils are also characteristic but are not present in this case.
  • • Option
  • • B. Botulism:
  • • Option D. Multiple Sclerosis: Multiple Sclerosis is a central nervous system demyelinating disorder presenting with varied neurological symptoms such as optic neuritis, motor deficits, and sensory changes. Ocular symptoms in MS are not characterized by fluctuating muscle weakness that improves with anticholinesterase medications, distinguishing it from MG.
  • • Option
  • • D. Multiple Sclerosis:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Myasthenia Gravis is marked by fluctuating muscle weakness that worsens with exertion and improves with rest, particularly affecting ocular and bulbar muscles. Diagnosis is confirmed by clinical presentation, response to anticholinesterase medications, and tests such as acetylcholine receptor antibodies and Single Fiber Electromyography.

questions.text: The spectacles shown in the image are not used for the management of which of the following? ( AIIMS May 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Hypermetropia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bifocal spectacles are not typically used for treating hypermetropia, which generally requires a uniform optical correction across the entire lens to aid in near tasks. Bifocals are instead beneficial in conditions requiring simultaneous correction for near and far vision, such as presbyopia, or specific needs following surgical interventions like in aphakia and pediatric pseudophakia.

questions.text: Following instrument is used to measure: (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Proptosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Hertel exophthalmometer is a specialized tool for assessing the extent of proptosis in conditions affecting the orbit and surrounding tissues, helping guide further diagnostic and therapeutic steps for conditions like thyroid eye disease.

questions.text: Which of the following procedure is shown in the image given below? ( INICET May 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Anterior ethmoidal nerve block

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ An anterior ethmoidal nerve block is crucial for numbing the nasal cavity area, particularly in endonasal surgeries. It is essential for procedures requiring detailed work near the roof of the nasal cavity, reflecting the significance of understanding the specific nerve anatomy for effective anesthesia.

questions.text: What among the following is not true about retinitis pigmentosa? ( NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. ERG – normal

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In retinitis pigmentosa, the ERG is not normal; it shows progressive abnormalities reflecting the degeneration of photoreceptor cells. Other features include retinal pigmentation, pale waxy disc, and narrowing of retinal vessels.

questions.text: What is the typical weight range of rabbits used in ophthalmological research? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Rabbits used in ophthalmological experiments generally weigh between 1.5 to 2.5 kg. This weight range is ideal for handling and conducting precise ophthalmological studies.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. 0.5-1 kg - This weight range is too low for typical ophthalmological research involving rabbits.
  • • Option A. 0.5-1 kg
  • • Option C. 5-7 kg - This weight range is too high and not common for ophthalmological studies using rabbits.
  • • Option C. 5-7 kg
  • • Option D. 10-12 kg - This weight range is also too high and not suitable for standard ophthalmological experiments.
  • • Option D. 10-12 kg

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The typical weight range for rabbits used in ophthalmological research is 1.5-2.5 kg, making them suitable for handling and detailed eye studies.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions do you see punched-out lesions of the retina? ( INICET May 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The appearance of punched-out lesions in the retina is crucial for diagnosing toxoplasmosis. This understanding can aid in distinguishing toxoplasmosis from other infectious or congenital conditions that affect the retina, guiding appropriate diagnostic and therapeutic interventions.

questions.text: You can use a stenopaeic slit for all of the following except? ( AIIMS Nov 2018)

options.label: D
options.text: To find out the axis in astigmatism

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Corneal tattooing

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Uses of stenopaeic slit test:
  • ➤ Fincham's test: to differentiate between the colored halos due to cataract and corneal edema due to glaucoma. To find out the optimal site for optical iridectomy in case of corneal opacities. To find out the axis in astigmatism.
  • ➤ Fincham's test: to differentiate between the colored halos due to cataract and corneal edema due to glaucoma.
  • ➤ To find out the optimal site for optical iridectomy in case of corneal opacities.
  • ➤ To find out the axis in astigmatism.

questions.text: A patient has presented for a routine eye evaluation. You have checked his visual acuity using Snellen's chart and found it to be 6/6. What is the minimum angle of resolution? ( INICET Nov 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 5 minutes of arc

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The minimum angle of resolution for someone with a visual acuity of 6/6 using a Snellen chart is 5 minutes of arc. This indicates the precise and detailed visual capability required to resolve fine details at a standard distance, a fundamental concept in understanding and assessing visual acuity in clinical settings.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient with progressive painless loss of vision presents to the ophthalmology OPD. Fundus picture of the patient is given below. What could be the probable finding and the cause of it? ( NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Hard exudate, Diabetes mellitus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hard exudates are characteristic findings in diabetic retinopathy, indicating chronic localized edema and composed of leaked lipoproteins and lipid-filled macrophages. They present as small, discrete yellowish, waxy areas with distinct margins in the retina.

questions.text: Identify the site of the lesion: ( INICET May 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Left occipital lobe

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A lesion in the left occipital lobe is the most likely cause of the right homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing shown in the visual field tests. This understanding is critical for accurately diagnosing the underlying condition, potentially a vascular event, and directing appropriate management and intervention strategies.

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency and his ocular examination reveals the following. Which of the following is not done initially? ( AIIMS May 2019)
questions.correct_answer: A. Removal of the foreign body
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Removal of the foreign body

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of ocular injuries involving foreign bodies, immediate removal is not advised due to the potential for further damage. Initial steps should focus on assessment, stabilization, and prevention of infection, followed by careful planning and execution of the foreign body removal under appropriate surgical conditions.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with a history of hypertension and poorly controlled diabetes presents to his ophthalmologist with complaints of gradually worsening vision in both eyes over the past year. His intraocular pressure is found to be elevated, and fundoscopy reveals optic disc cupping with nerve fiber layer thinning. Based on this finding, which of the following pupillary abnormalities is most commonly associated with primary open-angle glaucoma?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • A relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD), also known as a Marcus Gunn pupil, is an important clinical sign in primary open-angle glaucoma, indicating asymmetric optic nerve damage. It occurs when the affected eye has a defect in the afferent pathway of the pupillary light reflex. During the swinging flashlight test, the pupil of the affected eye dilates slightly when the light is shone on it, instead of remaining constricted as it would in a normal response. This finding reflects early and often asymmetric optic nerve damage seen in glaucoma.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Light-near dissociation Light-near dissociation is characterized by pupils that do not constrict in response to light but do constrict during accommodation, commonly seen in conditions like Argyll Robertson pupil and Parinaud syndrome. It is not typically associated with glaucoma.
  • • Option
  • • A. Light-near dissociation
  • • Option C. Anisocoria Anisocoria refers to unequal pupil sizes and can be physiological or related to various neurological conditions. It does not specifically indicate optic nerve damage or glaucoma.
  • • Option
  • • C. Anisocoria
  • • Option D. Horner’s syndrome Horner’s syndrome is characterized by ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis due to sympathetic pathway disruption. It does not involve the optic nerve or the afferent pathway and is unrelated to glaucoma.
  • • Option
  • • D. Horner’s syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) is a key clinical finding in primary open-angle glaucoma that signals asymmetric optic nerve damage. This condition is identified by the swinging flashlight test, which shows an abnormal pupillary response, reflecting the impact of glaucoma on the optic nerve pathways.

questions.text: A patient who is a known case of angle-closure glaucoma has been diagnosed with major depressive disorder. Which of the following drugs have to be avoided in this patient? ( INICET Nov 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Amitriptyline

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with angle-closure glaucoma, medications with anticholinergic properties, such as Amitriptyline, should be avoided due to their potential to increase intraocular pressure and exacerbate the condition.

questions.text: What was ETDRS study related to? ( AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Diabetic Macular edema

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The ETDRS study established the beneficial effects of photocoagulation in treating diabetic macular edema, recommending it as an early treatment option to prevent vision loss in patients with clinically significant macular edema.

questions.text: Which of the following helps to differentiate a fixed dilated pupil? ( INICET Nov 2020) Phenylephrine 1% Pilocarpine 0.1% Pilocarpine Cocaine 0.5% Epinephrine
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pilocarpine at concentrations of 1% and 0.1% is crucial for differentiating causes of fixed dilated pupils, with 1% identifying pharmacological blockade or nerve palsy, and 0.1% detecting hypersensitivity in cases like Adie's pupil.

questions.text: Extra row of eyelashes behind the grey line is called as? ( NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Distichiasis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Distichiasis is the condition where an extra row of eyelashes grows behind the normal lash line, often leading to corneal irritation and requiring treatment such as cryotherapy or electrolysis to prevent complications.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is not used in rheumatoid arthritis? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Febuxostat

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Febuxostat is specifically used to manage gout by lowering uric acid levels and does not have a role in the treatment regimen for rheumatoid arthritis, which typically involves DMARDs and biologic agents aimed at controlling systemic inflammation and preventing joint damage.

References:

  • ↳ Reference - Harrison/Rheumatology/RA/Chap 358

questions.text: A patient is prescribed a corrective lens with the following prescription: -1D spherical, -2D cylinder at 180 degrees. What type of refractive error is being corrected? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) With the rule astigmatism

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When prescribed corrective lenses for astigmatism, understanding the orientation and type of astigmatism (with the rule, against the rule, simple, or mixed) is crucial for ensuring the correct lens type and orientation is used, thus maximizing visual clarity and health.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of pterygium? ( INICET Nov 2022)

options.label: C
options.text: The parts of a pterygium are head, neck and body.

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Rate of recurrence is 95%

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pterygium's recurrence after surgical removal depends greatly on the surgical technique and the use of adjuvant therapies, not inherently 95% as previously thought. Effective management includes surgical excision combined with conjunctival autografts and adjuvant therapy to reduce the risk of recurrence significantly.

questions.text: Ligation of common hepatic artery will impair blood supply in?(NEET PG 2020)

options.label: A
options.text: Right gastric and right gastroepiploic artery

options.label: B
options.text: Right gastric and left gastric artery

options.label: C
options.text: Right gastroepiploic and short gastric vessels

options.label: D
options.text: Right gastric and short gastric vessels

questions.correct_answer: A. Right gastric and right gastroepiploic artery
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Right gastric and right gastroepiploic artery

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ligation of the common hepatic artery affects the blood supply to both the right gastric and right gastroepiploic arteries due to their derivation from the hepatic proper and gastroduodenal arteries respectively.

questions.text: A patient came to the medical OPD with complaints of polyuria. He has a history of undergoing total hypophysectomy. His Na + levels are found to be 155 mEq/L, urine osmolality was 200 mOsm/L. What is the definitive management? (NEET PG 2023)

options.label: A
options.text: DDAVP for 2 weeks and then discontinue

options.label: C
options.text: Upsetting of receptors so no treatment is required

questions.explanation:
Ans. B. DDAVP supplementation for lifelong

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with central diabetes insipidus following total hypophysectomy, lifelong desmopressin (DDAVP) supplementation is required to manage symptoms and prevent complications from persistent polyuria and hypernatremia.

questions.text: The given image illustrates which of the following conditions? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The image shows an attempt at lateral gaze away from the lesion side, where the abducting eye overshoots the target, leading to dissociated nystagmus. This feature is characteristic of internuclear ophthalmoplegia, where there is a lesion in the medial longitudinal fasciculus, disrupting communication between the abducens nucleus and the contralateral medial rectus subnucleus. This condition affects the adduction of the ipsilateral eye during saccades, causing either slow or absent movement. If the internuclear ophthalmoplegia is bilateral, the abduction saccades may also be impaired.
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option A. Horizontal gaze palsy : This condition involves the inability to move both eyes in the same direction, typically without the dissociated nystagmus seen in internuclear ophthalmoplegia.
  • • Option A. Horizontal gaze palsy
  • • Option C. Third nerve palsy : It is usually associated with symptoms like ptosis, eye deviation down and out, and pupil dilation, none of which are seen in the image provided.
  • • Option C. Third nerve palsy
  • • Option D. Duane retraction syndrome : This is a congenital condition where the eye movement is restricted due to abnormal development of the cranial nerves. The findings in the image do not align with this condition's characteristic restricted abduction or adduction.
  • • Option D. Duane retraction syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Internuclear ophthalmoplegia is characterized by impaired adduction of the affected eye and dissociated nystagmus in the abducting eye during lateral gaze.

questions.text: Which of the following is not useful for hemoglobin estimation by the colorimetric test? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) RBC pipette

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The RBC pipette is not useful for hemoglobin estimation by the colorimetric (Sahli's) method, as it is designed for cell counting rather than for the preparation and color comparison required in this test.

questions.text: Condition shown below is due to which vitamin deficiency?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Vitamin A

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Function: Vitamin A plays a vital role in the growth and development of human cells, controlling the immune system by preventing infections, and activating white blood cells Deficiency Symptoms: Vitamin A deficiency can lead to night blindness, dry skin, poor immune function, and impaired growth and development.
  • ➤ Function: Vitamin A plays a vital role in the growth and development of human cells, controlling the immune system by preventing infections, and activating white blood cells
  • ➤ Function:
  • ➤ Deficiency Symptoms: Vitamin A deficiency can lead to night blindness, dry skin, poor immune function, and impaired growth and development.
  • ➤ Deficiency Symptoms:

References:

  • ↳ Reference : Harper’s 31 st ed/pg- 530

questions.text: Which of the following is a new approved drug for Rett syndrome. ( INICET May 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Trofinetide

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Trofinetide is a newly approved drug for Rett syndrome, exhibiting neuroprotective properties similar to those of glypromate (GPE), and is beneficial for treating the symptoms of this genetic disorder.

questions.text: Which of the following muscles are supplied by the lateral plantar nerve? ( INICET Nov 2023) Abductor hallucis Flexor digitorum accessorius Flexor hallucis brevis First lumbrical First interossei
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 2 and 5

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The lateral plantar nerve supplies the flexor digitorum accessorius (quadratus plantae) and the first interossei muscles in the foot.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the surgeon with a recurrent inguinal hernia. The surgeon decides to perform a hernioplasty, and the patient inquiries about the most appropriate type of mesh to be used. The surgeon wants to ensure that the patient is aware of the various types of meshes that can be used in hernioplasty. Which of the following is the most appropriate mesh for use in hernioplasty? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.correct_answer: D. Lightweight mesh with large pores
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Lightweight mesh with large pores

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most appropriate mesh to use in hernioplasty is a lightweight mesh with large pores. Lightweight meshes induce a less-pronounced foreign body reaction and decreased inflammatory response, leading to better tissue incorporation, increased prosthesis compliance, and decreased patient discomfort and pain. Meshes with large pores allow for increased soft tissue ingrowth and exhibit less inflammatory infiltrate, connective tissue, and scar bridging. This results in less adhesion, better tissue incorporation, and decreased patient discomfort and pain. “Meshes with thinner strands and larger spaces (pores) between them are preferred because they have better tissue integration, less contracture, less foreign body reaction, more flexibility and improved comfort.” Bailey 28 th Ed. Pg 1063. Meshes used in hernioplasty can be synthetic or biological, with synthetic meshes made from Polypropylene, Polyester, or PTFE.
  • ➤ The most appropriate mesh to use in hernioplasty is a lightweight mesh with large pores.
  • ➤ Lightweight meshes induce a less-pronounced foreign body reaction and decreased inflammatory response, leading to better tissue incorporation, increased prosthesis compliance, and decreased patient discomfort and pain.
  • ➤ Meshes with large pores allow for increased soft tissue ingrowth and exhibit less inflammatory infiltrate, connective tissue, and scar bridging. This results in less adhesion, better tissue incorporation, and decreased patient discomfort and pain.
  • ➤ “Meshes with thinner strands and larger spaces (pores) between them are preferred because they have better tissue integration, less contracture, less foreign body reaction, more flexibility and improved comfort.” Bailey 28 th Ed. Pg 1063.
  • ➤ Meshes used in hernioplasty can be synthetic or biological, with synthetic meshes made from Polypropylene, Polyester, or PTFE.

questions.text: Mrs. Kumar, a 60-year-old woman, has been experiencing difficulty swallowing and a feeling of pressure in her chest. Her doctor orders an ultrasound, which reveals a retrosternal goiter. The commonest surgical approach to a retrosternal goiter is via: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Neck

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The commonest surgical approach to a retrosternal goiter is via the neck. This is because the thyroid gland is anatomically located in the neck, and even when a goiter extends behind the sternum into the chest, the neck provides the most direct and least invasive access for surgical removal. The retrosternal portion of the goiter can usually be mobilized and delivered into the neck for excision without the need for more invasive thoracic approaches. The vascular supply of the goiter also predominantly comes from cervical vessels like the inferior thyroid artery, making the neck approach feasible and effective.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Chest: Surgical approaches through the chest are typically not used for retrosternal goiters. Accessing the thyroid gland through the chest would involve more invasive procedures, such as thoracotomy, and is generally reserved for rare cases with specific indications, such as very large goiters extending deeply into the chest cavity.
  • • Option B. Chest:
  • • Option C. Median Sternotomy: Median sternotomy involves cutting through the breastbone (sternum) to access structures within the chest, particularly the heart and major blood vessels. While median sternotomy is common for cardiac surgeries, it is not the primary approach for treating retrosternal goiters, which can typically be addressed via the neck.
  • • Option C. Median Sternotomy:
  • • Option D. None of the above: This option is incorrect because the neck is the commonest and preferred approach for the surgical removal of retrosternal goiters.
  • • Option D. None of the above:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most common and preferred surgical approach for a retrosternal goiter is via the neck due to its direct access to the thyroid gland and the feasibility of mobilizing the goiter from this region.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis of an old lady who sustained a fall and presented with a headache and neurological symptoms a few days later? ( INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Subdural Hematoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Given the history of a fall and the delayed onset of neurological symptoms, a subdural hematoma (option D) is the most likely diagnosis in this case.

questions.text: Klenow fragment lacks the activity of? ( AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 5'-3' Exonuclease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Klenow fragment of DNA polymerase I lacks the 5'-3' exonuclease activity but retains the 5'->3' polymerase and 3'-5' exonuclease (proofreading) activities, making it useful for DNA synthesis and recombinant DNA technology.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presents to the ophthalmology clinic with complaints of progressive difficulty seeing objects in his peripheral vision, particularly noticing that he often misses things on the sides while driving. He reports experiencing mild, intermittent headaches over the past few weeks. His past medical history is unremarkable, and he has no known history of trauma or other neurological issues. A visual field test is performed, and the results are displayed in the image provided. Based on these findings, what is the most likely location of the lesion?
questions.explanation:
Ans.  B. Optic Chiasma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bitemporal hemianopia, typically resulting from a lesion at the optic chiasma, is most commonly caused by pituitary tumors. Identifying this visual field defect is crucial as it can be a sign of a potentially serious underlying condition that requires further investigation and management.

questions.text: Alkalinization of urine will be helpful in the treatment of poisoning due to? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Weakly acidic drugs

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Alkalinization of urine is an effective strategy to enhance the excretion of weakly acidic drugs by increasing their ionization and reducing their reabsorption in the renal tubules, thus promoting their elimination from the body. This method is particularly useful in cases of poisoning with weak acids, such as aspirin (salicylates).

questions.text: A 60-year-old postmenopausal female patient with a history of Colle's fracture comes to the outpatient department complaining of lower back pain. After undergoing a bone density test, her T score is found to be -2.5. Which of the following statements about the management of her condition is incorrect? (NEET PG 2021)

options.label: A
options.text: Teriparatide should be started before supplementing with bisphosphonates

options.label: B
options.text: Bisphosphonates are not given for more than a year

options.label: C
options.text: Calcium requirement is 1200 mg per day

options.label: D
options.text: Oral vitamin D3 is given along with oral calcium

questions.correct_answer: B. Bisphosphonates are not given for more than a year
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Bisphosphonates are not given for more than a year

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bisphosphonates are recommended for up to 5 years, not just one year, in the treatment of osteoporosis in postmenopausal women.

questions.text: All of the following statements about proto-oncogenes are true except? (AIIMS MAY 2021) BRCA1 is an oncogene. HER2neu is amplified only in a fraction of breast cancer. EGFR (+) is seen in non-small cell lung cancer. N-MYC is a tumor suppressor gene.
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ BRCA1 is a tumor suppressor gene and N-MYC is a proto-oncogene.
  • ➤ Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8 th edition 521-528
  • ➤ Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease 8 th edition 521-528

questions.text: Calculate the anion gap from the following values: Na+ = 137 mmol/L; K+ = 4 mmol/L; CI- =100 mmol/L; HCO3- = 15 mmol/L? (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 22 mmol/L

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 20-year-old patient presented to the clinic with a history of malabsorption, diarrhea, and poor appetite. Duodenal biopsy of the patient showed crypt hyperplasia, villi atrophy, and CD8+ cells in lamina propria. What is the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Celiac disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Celiac disease is characterized by malabsorption, diarrhea, poor appetite, crypt hyperplasia, villous atrophy, and increased intraepithelial CD8+ T lymphocytes. It is diagnosed by serologic tests and confirmed with a duodenal biopsy. Treatment includes a strict gluten-free diet.

questions.text: A patient presenting with bleeding gums and easy bruisability was diagnosed with scurvy. What is the biochemical basis of scurvy?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Defective collagen formation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following is not a method of administering free-flow oxygen in a neonate? (INICET MAY 2024)

options.label: A
options.text: Bag and mask ventilation with oxygen inlet

options.label: D
options.text: Bag and mask ventilation without oxygen inlet

questions.correct_answer: D. Bag and mask ventilation without oxygen inlet
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Free-flow oxygen can be administered using methods that allow passive flow of oxygen, such as a face mask or tubing near the mouth and nose. Bag and mask ventilation without an oxygen inlet does not allow for free-flow oxygen administration.

questions.text: The following table gives BP values before and after administration of drug 'X'. What would be the probable mechanism of action of drug 'X'? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.correct_answer: D. ﻿﻿﻿ β1 agonist and β2 agonist
questions.explanation:
Ans. D.β1 agonist and β2 agonist

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The combination of increased systolic blood pressure, decreased diastolic blood pressure, and increased heart rate suggests that drug 'X' acts as a β1 and β2 agonist, leading to increased cardiac output and vasodilation.

questions.text: Laboratory investigations of a patient being evaluated for jaundice show elevated bilirubin and alkaline phosphatase levels. Levels of the remaining liver enzymes are normal. What is the likely diagnosis? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Obstructive jaundice

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases where laboratory investigations reveal elevated bilirubin and alkaline phosphatase with normal other liver enzymes, obstructive jaundice should be considered as the most likely diagnosis.

questions.text: Indications for surgery (including biopsy) in a patient with Potts spine are all except: ( INICET May 2020)
questions.correct_answer: B. Cold abscess without neurological involvement
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Cold abscess without neurological involvement

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Presence of cold abscess without any neurological involvement is not an indication for biopsy or surgical treatment of Pott’s spine. Neurological involvement which is deteriorating with time is an important indication for surgical intervention.
  • ➤ Presence of cold abscess without any neurological involvement is not an indication for biopsy or surgical treatment of Pott’s spine.
  • ➤ Neurological involvement which is deteriorating with time is an important indication for surgical intervention.

questions.text: A patient with rheumatoid arthritis is being treated with methotrexate and low-dose corticosteroids for the past 4 months. However, the disease is still progressing. What would be your recommendation for the further management of this patient? (NEET PG 2019)

options.label: A
options.text: Stop oral methotrexate and start parenteral methotrexate

questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Add sulfasalazine and hydroxychloroquine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When a patient with rheumatoid arthritis does not respond adequately to initial therapy with methotrexate and corticosteroids, the addition of other DMARDs such as sulfasalazine and hydroxychloroquine can be beneficial.
  • ➤ Drugs:
  • ➤ Drugs:
  • ➤ Methotrexate: Start 10mg/week → max 25mg/week along with Folic acid twice/week Check ocular fundus before HCQ initiation Leflunomide, sulfasalazine other group of drugs. Sulfasalazine is safe in pregnancy !! Symptomatic relief with NSAID and short course corticosteroids.
  • ➤ Methotrexate: Start 10mg/week → max 25mg/week along with Folic acid twice/week
  • ➤ Methotrexate:
  • ➤ Check ocular fundus before HCQ initiation
  • ➤ Leflunomide, sulfasalazine other group of drugs.
  • ➤ Sulfasalazine is safe in pregnancy !!
  • ➤ Sulfasalazine is safe in pregnancy !!
  • ➤ Symptomatic relief with NSAID and short course corticosteroids.

References:

  • ↳ Reference - Harrison/Rheumatoid arthritis/ Chap 358

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents to the ophthalmology clinic with complaints of redness, itching, and irritation at the corners of his eyes for the past week. He reports that these symptoms started gradually and have been worsening, especially after frequent rubbing. He also notices some discharge that accumulates at the corners of his eyes, which sometimes appears foamy. On examination, there is inflammation and mild excoriation at the inner canthi with no signs of corneal involvement. The rest of his ocular exam, including visual acuity and pupillary response, is normal. The physician suspects an infection and plans to start appropriate treatment after identifying the causative organism. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Moraxella lacunata is a gram-negative diplobacillus that is the most common causative organism of angular conjunctivitis. This condition is characterized by inflammation, irritation, and a foamy or sticky discharge localized at the inner or outer corners of the eyes. The infection often originates from nasal secretions that spread to the eyes via contaminated hands or objects. Moraxella species are frequently found in the nasal passages of healthy individuals, and when transferred to the eyes, they cause localized canthal inflammation. Treatment typically involves topical antibiotics such as oxytetracycline, with a course lasting 10 to 14 days, which effectively resolves the infection.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Corynebacterium species: While Corynebacterium can cause chronic conjunctivitis, it does not typically present with localized canthal inflammation or foamy discharge. The clinical features seen here are more consistent with angular conjunctivitis caused by Moraxella.
  • • Option
  • • A. Corynebacterium species:
  • • Option B. Streptococcus viridans: Streptococcus viridans is generally associated with endophthalmitis or other ocular infections, but it does not typically cause the localized angular inflammation and discharge seen in this patient.
  • • Option
  • • B. Streptococcus viridans:
  • • Option D. Staphylococcus epidermidis: Staphylococcus epidermidis is a common cause of chronic blepharitis and conjunctivitis, often associated with biofilm formation on eyelid margins or ocular surfaces, rather than the distinct canthal involvement and discharge typical of Moraxella-related angular conjunctivitis.
  • • Option
  • • D. Staphylococcus epidermidis:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Moraxella lacunata is the leading cause of angular conjunctivitis, characterized by localized inflammation and discharge at the corners of the eyes. The infection spreads from nasal secretions to the eyes via contaminated hands, and the preferred treatment is topical antibiotics, typically oxytetracycline, administered for 10 to 14 days.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most potent stimulator of naive T-cells? ( INICET NOV 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Mature dendritic cells

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mature dendritic cells are the most potent stimulators of naive T cells due to their high levels of MHC-II and costimulatory molecules.

questions.text: Which skull foramen is formed by 3 bones? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Foramen lacerum

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The foramen lacerum is a triangular-shaped foramen located in the skull base. It is largely filled with cartilage in a living individual and serves as a landmark rather than a conduit for significant neurovascular structures (though some smaller emissary veins and nerves might pass through). Importantly, the internal carotid artery courses superiorly to this foramen but doesn't pass through it. The foramen lacerum is bordered by three bones:
  • • Petrous part of the temporal bone: This bone forms the posterior and medial aspect of the foramen lacerum. Sphenoid bone: The greater wing of the sphenoid bone forms the anterior and lateral aspect of the foramen lacerum. Basilar part of the occipital bone: The basilar part of the occipital bone forms the posterior and medial aspect of the foramen lacerum.
  • • Petrous part of the temporal bone: This bone forms the posterior and medial aspect of the foramen lacerum.
  • • Petrous part of the temporal bone:
  • • Sphenoid bone: The greater wing of the sphenoid bone forms the anterior and lateral aspect of the foramen lacerum.
  • • Sphenoid bone:
  • • greater wing
  • • Basilar part of the occipital bone: The basilar part of the occipital bone forms the posterior and medial aspect of the foramen lacerum.
  • • Basilar part of the occipital bone:
  • • The foramen lacerum is covered by a fibrous membrane, which makes it difficult to see and access.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Foramen magnum: The foramen magnum is the largest foramen of the skull and is located in its base. Through it pass the medulla oblongata (which becomes the spinal cord as it exits the skull), the vertebral arteries, spinal parts of the accessory nerves, and the anterior and posterior spinal arteries. It is formed entirely by the occipital bone.
  • • Option B. Foramen magnum:
  • • Option C. Foramen rotundum: The foramen rotundum is located in the greater wing of the sphenoid bone. Through this foramen, the maxillary branch of the trigeminal nerve (V2) exits the cranial cavity to enter the pterygopalatine fossa. It is formed solely by the sphenoid bone.
  • • Option C. Foramen rotundum:
  • • Option D. Foramen jugulare (jugular foramen): The jugular foramen is a large irregular opening located between the petrous part of the temporal bone and the occipital bone. This foramen transmits the internal jugular vein and several cranial nerves: the glossopharyngeal (IX), vagus (X), and accessory (XI) nerves. It is formed by two bones:
  • • Option D. Foramen jugulare (jugular foramen):
  • • Anterolaterally: the petrous part of the temporal bone. Posteromedially: the occipital bone.
  • • Anterolaterally: the petrous part of the temporal bone.
  • • Posteromedially: the occipital bone.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The foramen lacerum's formation by three bones (the petrous part of the temporal bone, greater wing of the sphenoid bone, and basilar part of the occipital bone) makes it unique among the foramina at the base of the skull. Understanding its anatomical context and relations is crucial for interpreting imaging and planning surgeries involving the cranial base.

questions.text: A teenage girl presented with irregular cycles and increased facial hair. Her ovaries showed increased volume. Which of the following are used in the first line treatment? (INICET MAY 2021) Laparoscopic ovarian drilling Anti-androgens Lifestyle modifications Combined oral contraceptive pills
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 2, 3, 4

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The clinical presentation of irregular menstrual cycles and increased facial hair, combined with increased ovarian volume, is suggestive of polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS) . The first-line treatment options for PCOS typically include:
  • • polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS)
  • • Anti-androgens (2): These medications help reduce symptoms related to excess androgens, such as facial hair and acne. Common examples include spironolactone.
  • • Anti-androgens
  • • Lifestyle modifications (3): These are crucial for managing PCOS. Weight loss and exercise can improve insulin sensitivity and help regulate menstrual cycles.
  • • Lifestyle modifications
  • • Combined oral contraceptive pills (4): These are used to regulate menstrual cycles, reduce hyperandrogenism symptoms (like hirsutism), and provide endometrial protection.
  • • Combined oral contraceptive pills
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Laparoscopic ovarian drilling (1): This is a surgical procedure used to treat PCOS, but it is generally considered a second-line treatment. It is typically performed when medical management fails to achieve the desired results.
  • • Laparoscopic ovarian drilling

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The first-line treatments for PCOS include anti-androgens, lifestyle modifications, and combined oral contraceptive pills.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 460, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 460, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6 th edition

questions.text: A patient who was receiving warfarin therapy for atrial fibrillation was prescribed a cephalosporin antibiotic to treat a lower respiratory tract infection. He returned to the hospital after developing hemarthrosis. Which of the following cephalosporins is most likely to have caused this? ( INICET Nov 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Cefoperazone

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cefoperazone is the cephalosporin most likely to cause hemarthrosis in a patient on warfarin therapy due to its MTT group, which can inhibit the VKOR enzyme and potentiate the anticoagulant effects of warfarin. Other cephalosporins like cefixime, ceftobiprole, and ceftazidime do not have this interaction and are less likely to cause such bleeding complications.
  • ➤ Cefoperazone

questions.text: The instrument given in the image is: (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Jackson-Pratt drain

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective :
  • ➤ The Jackson-Pratt drain is a closed drainage system that uses gentle suction to remove fluids from surgical sites, helping prevent fluid accumulation and reducing infection risk.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to the ophthalmology clinic with complaints of redness, tearing, and a mild foreign body sensation in her right eye for the past few days. She reports no significant ocular history but mentions recent symptoms of fever, cough, and anosmia. She has no known allergies or history of eye trauma. Her visual acuity is unaffected, and there is no pain with eye movement. On examination, there is mild conjunctival injection without discharge or chemosis. The ophthalmologist is concerned about the possibility of a systemic viral infection. What is the most common ocular manifestation associated with the suspected viral infection in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Follicular conjunctivitis is the most common ocular manifestation observed in patients with COVID-19. The virus affects the eyes due to the presence of ACE-2 receptors on the cornea and conjunctiva, which act as entry points for SARS-CoV-2. Follicular conjunctivitis appears as mild conjunctival redness with or without discharge, and it can occasionally be the only symptom of COVID-19, highlighting the virus's potential to impact the eyes. Other ocular symptoms include tearing, itching, and a foreign body sensation, but follicular conjunctivitis remains the predominant ocular finding.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Episcleritis: Episcleritis is a localized, benign inflammation of the episclera often associated with autoimmune conditions rather than viral infections like COVID-19. It presents with mild redness and discomfort, which can be mistaken for conjunctivitis but is less common in COVID-19.
  • • Option
  • • A. Episcleritis:
  • • Option B. Anterior uveitis: Anterior uveitis is characterized by inflammation of the iris and ciliary body, leading to photophobia, pain, and visual disturbances. It is not commonly associated with COVID-19 and would present with different symptoms such as eye pain and photophobia, unlike the mild conjunctivitis observed.
  • • Option
  • • B. Anterior uveitis:
  • • Option D. Keratitis: Keratitis involves inflammation of the cornea and can present with severe pain, photophobia, and vision changes. This condition is not a common manifestation of COVID-19 and typically has more severe symptoms compared to follicular conjunctivitis.
  • • Option
  • • D. Keratitis:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Follicular conjunctivitis is the most common ocular manifestation seen in patients with COVID-19. It is crucial for healthcare providers, especially ophthalmologists, to be aware of this presentation and to consider COVID-19 testing in patients with unexplained conjunctival symptoms, including Most common ocular symptoms: Dry eye or foreign body sensation, redness, tearing, itching, eye pain, and discharge.
  • ➤ Most common ocular symptoms:
  • ➤ Most common ocular manifestation: Mild follicular conjunctivitis, which can appear as the only sign and symptom of COVID-19.
  • ➤ Most common ocular manifestation:
  • ➤ Other less frequent ocular complications: Hemorrhagic conjunctivitis, dry eye disease, episcleritis, chemosis, and photophobia.
  • ➤ Other less frequent ocular complications:
  • ➤ Intraocular complications that may occur: Retinal artery occlusions, hemorrhages, and cotton wool spots caused by complement-mediated thrombotic angiopathy.
  • ➤ Intraocular complications that may occur:
  • ➤ Patients with conjunctivitis should undergo a nasopharyngeal RT-PCR test for COVID-19 to rule out systemic infection.
  • ➤ Physicians and ophthalmologists should exercise caution when examining patients with conjunctivitis and wear eye-protective gear in addition to face masks and other protective devices.

questions.text: A clinician is conducting a study on the occurrence of a rare disease within a specific population over a certain time period. The disease cases occur independently, and the average rate of occurrence is constant. Which statistical distribution best represents the likelihood of observing a specific number of disease cases within this defined time period? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Poisson distribution

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Poisson distribution is used to model the number of rare disease cases occurring independently in a fixed period of time.
  • ➤ The Poisson distribution is used to model the number of rare disease cases occurring independently in a fixed period of time.

questions.text: Which of the following is wrong regarding primary and secondary immune response? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation: Ans. D) 4

questions.text: You and your friend plan for a mountain trip for the day after. What medication would you advise him to help with his motion sickness? ( AIIMS Nov 2017)

options.label: A
options.text: Ranitidine tablet before start of trip

options.label: C
options.text: Scopolamine patch the night before trip

options.label: D
options.text: Omeprazole the night before and before starts of trip

questions.correct_answer: C. Scopolamine patch the night before trip
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Scopolamine patch the night before trip

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Scopolamine, particularly in the form of a transdermal patch, is the drug of choice for the prevention of motion sickness. The patch should be applied the night before the trip to ensure it is effective in preventing the symptoms of motion sickness. Ranitidine and Omeprazole are not effective. Dimenhydrinate is an anti-histaminic drug which is not as effective as scopolamine.
